user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY_NP) && defined(HAVE_GETPID)
  /* NetBSD style */
  cpuset_t *cpuset_ptr;
  cpuset_ptr = cpuset_create ();
  if (NULL != cpuset_ptr)
  {
    if (0 == sched_getaffinity_np (getpid (), cpuset_size (cpuset_ptr),
                                   cpuset_ptr))
    {
      cpuid_t cpu_num;
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCONF) && defined(HAVE_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF)
      unsigned int max_num = 0;
      long sc_value;
      sc_value = sysconf (_SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN);
      if (0 < sc_value)
        max_num = (unsigned int) sc_value;
      if (0 < max_num)
      {
        ret = 0;
        for (cpu_num = 0; cpu_num < max_num; ++cpu_num)
          if (0 < cpuset_isset (cpu_num, cpuset_ptr))
            ++ret;
      }
      else /* Combined with the next 'if' */
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCONF && HAVE_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF */
      if (1)
      {
        int res;
        cpu_num = 0;
        ret = 0;
        do
        {
          res = cpuset_isset (cpu_num++, cpuset_ptr);
          if (0 < res)
            ++ret;
        } while (0 <= res);
      }
#ifdef __NetBSD__
      if (0 == ret)
      {
        /* On NetBSD "unset" affinity (exactly zero CPUs) means
           "all CPUs are available". */
        ret = mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_ ();
      }
#endif /* __NetBSD__ */
    }
    cpuset_destroy (cpuset_ptr);
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY_NP && HAVE_GETPID */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The rest of the code does not present obvious unreachable-code issues and need not be investigated for MISRA Rule 2.1 in this function:

- The top-level #if/#endif (HAVE_SCHED_GETAFFINITY_NP && HAVE_GETPID) guards the whole cpuset-based logic; code inside that block is conditionally compiled and thus not "unreachable" in the compiled output when the macros are defined.
- The cpuset allocation, NULL check (if (NULL != cpuset_ptr)), and cpuset_destroy(cpuset_ptr) form a normal runtime path: cpuset_create may return NULL or non-NULL, so the guarded code is reachable when cpuset_ptr != NULL.
- The sched_getaffinity_np(getpid(), ...) call is executed at runtime and the subsequent block is entered only when it returns 0; this is a valid runtime branch and therefore not statically unreachable.
- The initialisation ret = -1 and the final test if (0 >= ret) return -1; return ret; are reachable and form the normal return behaviour when the affinity-based counting is not performed or yields non-positive results.
- Local variable declarations (ret, cpuset_ptr, cpu_num, etc.) and ordinary statements not listed above are standard and reachable depending on the runtime and preprocessor configuration.

The three fragments reported above were selected because they involve constant condition / preprocessor interplay (the explicit if (1) used together with an #if ... else comment, and the NetBSD-specific fallback) which may create code that is effectively unreachable in certain compile-time or runtime configurations and therefore merit further investigation for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
